为什么摄影很重要？

这是我们都会时不时问的一个问题。毕竟，为什么我们总是在凌晨 4:00 起床去拍摄日出，而我们躺在床上却可以感到温暖舒适呢？当我们可以看电视或与朋友外出时，为什么我们要花很长时间调整构图并学习摄影基础知识？

有时，当我们完全没有创造力并且按下快门按钮似乎是世界上最难的事情时，我们仍然坚持下去 - 但为什么呢？摄影有何魅力如此引人注目？

是什么激励我们继续前进？

在这篇文章中，我将分享我认为摄影很重要的九个原因。希望这些想法能帮助您找到清晰度和动力，并鼓励您捕捉图像，即使感觉一切都毫无意义，您应该永远放下相机。

让我们开始吧。

1.摄影帮助我们看到复杂世界的美丽

生活并不总是完美的。有时它是混乱的，有时是压倒性的，有时它只是简单的艰难。但即使在混乱和挣扎之中，也有一丝美丽等待被发现。这就是您的相机可以成为变革性工具的地方。

摄影训练你的眼睛去寻找那些闪光。当您通过镜头观看时，您不仅仅是在构图，更是在构图。你正在一个急需美的世界中积极寻找美。被雨水浸湿的花朵上的花瓣、日落的温暖色调或所爱之人的欢乐微笑都成为惊奇和欣赏的焦点。

能够捕捉到这种美有双重目的。首先，它提供了片刻的安慰，让我们暂时摆脱周围的混乱。其次，它持久地提醒人们，即使世界看似黑暗，但总有光明的地方。您的照片可以成为那些灯塔，鼓励您和其他人即使在平凡中也能发现美。

因此，即使世界看起来太复杂而难以处理，也要继续拍摄。你的镜头可以像筛子一样，过滤掉丑陋的东西，只留下美丽的东西。这样做时，你会发现这个世界尽管有缺陷，仍然充满了值得捕捉、值得珍惜的奇迹。

2. 我们的照片告诉我们什么对我们来说是重要的

当你问人们他们会从着火的房子里抢救什么财产时，最常见的答案之一是一本相册或一台包含所有数字图像的电脑。

很有趣，不是吗？即使在恐慌的时刻，我们也会抓起照片而不是贵重的珠宝。

这种保存记录记忆的冲动是一股强大的力量，它告诉我们很多关于摄影在我们生活中的作用，并说明我们始终渴望将最珍贵的时刻提炼成图像。

我们保存生活中的重要事件和人物。出生和生日、结婚和周年纪念日、假期和新房的仪式都被记录下来，因为它们很重要。

照片是我们生活的时间轴，充满了我们喜爱的面孔和地点。它们是我们的故事，我们可以与他人分享。

最终，我们拍摄的数千张照片构成了我们生活的叙述。

3.摄影记录了世界的本来面目

我们生活在旋风之中。前一刻你还是个在院子里玩耍的孩子，下一刻你就变成了一个有责任的成年人。世界不会停止，一刻也不会。有没有注意到汽车的发展速度有多快，或者天际线如何变化？真让人头晕。但这就是摄影像穿越时空的超级英雄一样突然出现的地方。

通过镜头捕捉世界让我们能够定格时间的瞬间。这不仅仅是历史地标或世界事件；摄影也可以记录小事。想想你童年的家，或者你在大学里开的车。照片使它们不朽，永远铭刻在相框中。

当您拍摄家人围坐在餐桌旁的照片时，您所做的不仅仅是创造一个纪念品。你正在记录那一刻的生活片段。这些快照成为无价之宝，让子孙后代得以一睹我们曾经了解的世界。

照片作为视觉教科书，提供有关生活、社会和我们周围不断变化的世界的课程。它们可以揭示时尚是如何演变的，或者社区在过去几十年里是如何变化的。这不仅仅是怀旧之情；它是人类历史的宏大和亲密的记录。

我鼓励您像历史学家一样使用相机。因为当你捕捉到转瞬即逝的日落或某人眼中的笑声时，你正在做一些意义深远的事情。你正在记录世界的本来面目，一个永远不会再一样的世界。

4. 照片是我们遗产的一部分

我记得我坐在火车上，经过一个操场，孩子们正立正等待学校一年一度的合影。前排坐着老师们，在他们后面，数百名孩子们打扮得漂漂亮亮，穿着制服。有那么一瞬间，整个集会都一动不动。当摄影师按下快门时，我们就过去了。

然后，就像慢动作一样，一大群人分散开来，就像孩子们逃离了被迫的静止状态一样。整齐的一排队伍消失了，分成了几个在踢球或与朋友挤在一起的人。

这些孩子都没有意识到这张照片可能会比他们活得更久。几代人之后，学校的照片可能会重新出现在阁楼的旧报纸中，有人会在新鲜、年轻的面孔中寻找他们的祖父。

照片很重要，因为它们定格了我们生活中那些平淡无奇、对当时的我们似乎并不重要的瞬间。一张照片的意义甚至可能不在于我们——相反，它可能对于那些寻找我们曾经的人或我们曾经知道的地方的人来说。

每张照片都可以是拼图的一小部分，可以完成我们生活的大图景。

5. 照片让我们能够分享和交流

图像不仅仅是简单的记录。摄影表达了我们人性中最好、最慷慨的部分——与他人分享我们认为美丽和有趣的事物的愿望。

你只需浏览众多的照片分享网站，就能看到这种冲动的发挥作用，数百万人在这些网站上分享他们对周围世界的个人、热情、有时甚至是古怪的看法。

换句话说，我们的图像可以与陌生人分享我们的生活。那有多强大？

6.摄影使我们成为艺术家

艺术并不局限于画廊和音乐厅。事实上，你不需要成为一名传统艺术家就能创造出令人惊叹的东西。这就是摄影的魔力。有了相机，任何人都可以成为艺术家。

将您的镜头视为您的画笔。框架是你的画布，光线是你的调色板。您可以自由地构图来激发情感、讲述故事或只是令人眼花缭乱。这是一种易于理解但又非常个性化的艺术形式，让您可以将自己的愿景投射到世界上。

我们都有独特的看待事物的方式。你拍摄日落、捕捉微笑、甚至聚焦一滴雨滴的方式都可以揭示你的个性。你的视角将成为你的艺术才华，让你在创作者的海洋中脱颖而出。

所以，不要低估你拍摄的照片的力量。无论您拍摄风景还是肖像，无论您拍摄黑白还是鲜艳的色彩，您都在创造艺术。你正在将普通的场景转变为非凡的视觉叙事。

对你的工作感到自豪。展示它、分享它、庆祝它。您是一位艺术家，拥有触手可及的自己的画廊。是时候认识到您的摄影的真正含义了：一种您可以一次一帧地表现出色的艺术形式。

7.摄影让我们能够表达自己

我们的图像可以表达欢乐和悲伤、惊奇和同情。人类的每一种情感都可以在摄影中找到一席之地。

多年来，我从未重视过阴天风景的照片，因为我相信色彩柔和、天空灰暗的土地上没有美丽。我希望这片土地充满色彩和活力。

然而，风景中缺乏色彩会让您寻找在明亮的阳光下经常被忽视的其他事物。这可能是山丘的对称性，也可能是从成千上万的森林中脱颖而出的一棵树。

为了进一步扩展这一点：

我成年后的大部分时间都患有抑郁症，摄影给了我一种语言来表达我无法用语言表达的感受。我们对精神疾病的词汇少之又少，但摄影让我能够用视觉语言来表达一些最困难的情绪。

与此相关的是，拍照的行为可以具有治疗作用。通过镜头聚焦，您成为自己情绪的观察者。你有机会克服你可能不知道自己有过的感受。

伟大的艺术往往源于脆弱。当您使用摄影来表达真实的自我时，您就加入了丰富的艺术家行列，他们利用自己的技艺来释放情感。从令人心碎的新闻摄影到令人回味的肖像，这些作品之所以能引起共鸣，是因为它们来自真诚的情感。

所以，拿起你的相机，不仅拍摄你所看到的，还要拍摄你所感受到的。这不仅仅是一个快照；它是你的情感的一个片段，被时间冻结了。通过您的照片，您可以分享您的内心世界，建立仅靠言语无法建立的联系。

8.摄影有感动我们的力量

照片可以吸引我们的注意力并直接表达我们的情感。有很多强有力的照片——比如尼克·乌特（Nick Ut）拍摄的一个哭泣的越南女孩的照片，她的衣服被凝固汽油弹烧毁了——可以让我们感受到一些东西。

在更微妙的层面上，摄影教会我们有关一系列情感的课程。悲伤有能力冲走我们生活的光明和色彩。没有什么神奇的方法可以恢复这些。我们必须要有耐心。但在等待的同时，我们可以寻找灰色中仍然存在的形状和图案。它们最终将引导我们回到色彩。在我生命中最悲伤的时刻，我用图像来表达恢复色彩的希望。

摄影，在最好的情况下，是一种强有力的语言，可以表达我们的情感。它使我们能够讲述我们的故事并向其他人展示我们对周围世界的看法。

9.摄影可以改变世界

一张照片可以激起观众的良心，煽动行动，甚至改变历史的进程。这不仅仅是艺术或自我表达的一种形式；它也是变革的推动者。您的相机可以成为揭示全球和社区中重要问题的强大盟友。

考虑一下新闻摄影的影响。战争、贫困和社会不公正的形象促使几代人采取行动。这些照片将我们听到的问题的面孔和故事呈现出来，让它们感觉更真实、更紧迫。然而，您不必前往战区才能发挥作用。您所在社区的日常斗争同样值得关注。

假设您家乡有一个公园受到开发的威胁。一张适时捕捉公园自然美景的照片可以让你的邻居团结起来保卫公园。或者也许您热衷于动物福利。您为收容所动物拍摄的令人心酸的图片可以鼓励其他人收养或捐赠。

摄影有能力超越单纯的观察，进入宣传领域。就像安塞尔·亚当斯 (Ansel Adams) 用他的相机保护优胜美地一样，您也可以用您的相机来保护和突出显示您关心的事物。范围不必很大；引起注意的行为往往足以引发变革。

无论是社会问题还是环境问题，都不要低估您的照片可以产生的影响。你不只是一个旁观者；你是塑造世界叙事的参与者。因此，拿起相机并有目的地拍摄，因为您的镜头很可能成为世界所需的催化剂。

为什么摄影很重要：最后的话

希望您现在能够更好地理解人们追求摄影的不同原因以及摄影的重要性。拿起相机的原因就像镜头背后的人一样多种多样。然而，贯穿每张照片的共同点是摄影可以产生的深远影响。这不仅仅是一种爱好或需要掌握的技能；这是一次丰富您的生活，也很可能丰富他人生活的旅程。

摄影捕捉的不仅仅是瞬间；它捕捉情感、现实和想法。它提供了技术技能和艺术表达的独特结合，邀请您不断发展。每次按下快门时，您都在参与一种人类已经接受了一个多世纪的讲故事形式。

因此，无论您将相机对准广阔的风景、繁华的城市景观，还是您所爱之人的眼睛，请记住这一点：您拍摄的每张照片都会为您的生活以及其他人的生活增加价值。摄影的重要性是深远的，其影响是不可估量的。

现在我很想知道：

你为什么做摄影？是什么促使你继续拍照？摄影对你的启发是什么？

在下面的评论中分享您的想法！

拍摄蜻蜓的 12 个技巧一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是理查德·比奇。

本文于 2023 年 11 月更新，由 Richard Beech 和 Steve Berardi 贡献。

蜻蜓和豆娘是迷人的昆虫，由于其鲜艳的颜色和醒目的图案而特别上镜。它们是昆虫微距摄影师的最爱，如果拍摄得好，效果会令人惊叹。

然而，拍摄蜻蜓有几个主要的困难：你的拍摄对象很容易受到惊吓，而且它们通常看起来好像永远不会降落，所以你可以拍摄它们！

幸运的是，拍摄豆娘和蜻蜓的精彩照片可能比您想象的更容易！通过正确的技术和一些研究，您可以像专业人士一样拍摄蜻蜓照片。以下是我最喜欢的一些提示和技巧，可以帮助您入门：

1.选择合适的设备

蜻蜓比大多数其他昆虫都大，这意味着您不需要专门的镜头即可拍摄出不错的照片；根据我的经验，蜻蜓可以用任何东西来拍摄，从傻瓜相机到顶级无反光镜机身。无论您使用什么设备，许多原理都是相同的。

也就是说，虽然好的变焦镜头（100-400mm 范围内）可以产生不错的效果，但专用微距镜头的优势在于可以提供更近的焦距以实现高倍率。

注意：如果您使用变焦镜头并且无法像您希望的那样近距离对焦，那么添加延长管将使其能够更近距离地对焦，并且应该会产生良好的效果。这是比购买专用微距镜头更便宜的选择。

然而，如果您打算定期拍摄蜻蜓，则较长的（150毫米、180毫米或200毫米）微距镜头可能是值得的投资；这样，您就可以在舒适的工作距离内拍摄充满画面的照片，而不会吓跑蜻蜓。

如果有帮助的话，我使用了 Sigma 150mm f/2.8 微距镜头来拍摄本文中的许多镜头！

2.找个好位置

在夏季，蜻蜓可以出现在任何有水的地方。某些物种来到小池塘，而其他物种则出现在河流或溪流附近。

豆娘的飞行能力通常较弱，往往停留在靠近水面的地方，而蜻蜓则飞得离水面较远，有时栖息在眼睛的高度。

我鼓励您在外出之前花一些时间研究当地的蜻蜓种类及其喜欢的栖息地。这样，当您带着相机在现场时，您至少可以定期找到一些潜在的拍摄对象！

另外，要做好泥泞的准备——您可能需要靠近水边的地面才能拍出好的照片。穿着合适的衣服，并尊重您所在的工作环境。

3.考虑一下天气

蜻蜓需要太阳的热量来温暖它们的身体并飞行，因此它们通常在晴朗、阳光明媚的日子最活跃。

但这并不意味着您也不应该在阴天寻找它们。它们会更难被发现，因为它们通常栖息在植被之间，但它们也更容易接近，因为它们在没有太阳热量的情况下很难飞走。

另外，您会在多云的天空中获得柔和的漫射光，这往往看起来很可爱，并为您的拍摄对象带来大量细节和色彩！

底线：不同的天气条件各有优缺点，因此请尝试一下，看看什么最适合您的拍摄风格。

4. 在现场观察你的拍摄对象

一旦发现蜻蜓，请花一些时间观察它的行为。您将很快了解它飞向哪里以及喜欢栖息在哪里；有些蜻蜓喜欢栖息在地面上，而另一些则喜欢栖息在草地或岩石上。

拍摄飞行中的蜻蜓可能非常棘手，因此当您刚开始时，我建议您尝试拍摄一些休息时的蜻蜓照片。

我发现，与其用相机追逐蜻蜓，不如留意它们降落的地方，在附近架起相机，然后等待。蜻蜓往往整天都会回到同一个地点，所以只要您有耐心，您就有很大的机会捕捉到精彩的照片。

如果你看到一只蜻蜓栖息在一根棍子上，你可以尝试缓慢而小心地接近，避免突然移动。你也许能够非常接近。但是，如果蜻蜓确实飞走了，请保持静止并等待几分钟。它很可能会返回并降落在同一地点。耐心是关键。

如果你足够幸运，发现一只正在吃东西的蜻蜓，你也许可以靠近一些；根据我的经验，他们似乎更关注他们的食物而不是摄影师！

我曾尝试并取得了一些成功，那就是把自己的栖息处——一根棍子或一根芦苇——放在靠近水面的地方，距离足够近，以便在蜻蜓决定降落在上面时可以拍摄一些照片。

5.早起

蜻蜓在一天中最热的时候更加活跃，因为它们需要太阳的热量来温暖它们以使其飞行。当您是蜻蜓摄影初学者时，更多的活动会让捕捉清晰、充满画面的照片变得更加困难。

因此，如果可能的话，我建议早上早些时候出去，那时天气稍凉，阳光也不会那么刺眼。您可能找不到那么多蜻蜓，但您发现的蜻蜓可​​能会停留更长时间，以便更近距离地接近。

如果你第一件事就出发，你甚至可能很幸运地拍到它们被清晨的露水覆盖的照片！

6.控制光圈以获得清晰的图像

清晰度对于蜻蜓和豆娘摄影至关重要，为了确保获得清晰的图像，您必须仔细控制景深。您需要尽可能多地聚焦蜻蜓；最大化这一效果的一种方法是纵向拍摄蜻蜓。

您会看到，确保相机的传感器与蜻蜓的身体平行将使您能够使用更宽的光圈，模糊任何分散注意力的背景，同时保持整个蜻蜓的焦点。

拍摄如此清晰的蜻蜓侧面照片并不总是可能的。在这种情况下，您可以通过缩小光圈来增加景深。我发现从 f/5.6 的光圈开始，然后拍摄一系列降至 f/11 左右或更小的照片，并相应地改变快门速度和 ISO，这很有用。

无论如何，请始终确保眼睛对焦并尽可能锐利！

7. 拍摄大量照片（从多个角度）

拍摄蜻蜓（或自然界中的任何物体）最有价值的部分之一是它让您有机会更仔细地观察您的拍摄对象。那里有许多蜻蜓和豆娘物种，它们都值得详细研究。

然而，有时，一个物种与另一个物种的唯一区别就是其翅膀上的几个点。因此，最好从多个不同角度拍摄照片，以帮助您稍后识别主题！

8. 注意您的设置

获得正确的曝光可能很棘手，尤其是在明亮的阳光下拍摄时。 （在当天早些时候或在稍微阴天的条件下拍摄，您将获得更柔和、漫射的光线，这使得正确曝光变得更加容易。）在光圈优先模式下工作会很有帮助，然后通过添加根据需要进行曝光补偿。

即使在栖息时，蜻蜓也可以做出许多快速动作，例如拍动翅膀或抽动头部。因此，您需要使用相对较快的快门速度。我建议连拍三到四张照片——当您检查照片时，您可能会发现一张照片比其他照片特别清晰。

您可以稍微提高 ISO设置以实现更快的快门速度和更窄的光圈，但我不建议使用超过 ISO 800 或 1600 的值来最大限度地提高图像质量。 （也就是说，有些相机提供非常好的高 ISO 功能，因此提前评估相机型号的功能并进行相应的工作总是一个好主意！）

如果您被迫使用稍慢的快门速度，三脚架可能会派上用场；然而，发现蜻蜓的地点并不总是非常适合三脚架。如果您决定手持相机进行拍摄，请确保手保持稳定、站稳，并确保相机或镜头的图像稳定功能已打开（如果有）。

9. 关闭自动对焦

您可能会惊讶地发现，通过关闭自动对焦并手动对焦，通常可以拍摄出更清晰的蜻蜓照片。

您会发现，在高放大倍率下工作时，自动对焦通常会很困难 - 因此，除非您要拍摄画面中很小的蜻蜓，否则通常值得使用镜头的手动对焦设置。

起初，这可能感觉相当困难。毕竟，您将使用镜头上的环进行对焦，这可能非常挑剔！但通过练习，你会发现手动对焦不仅可行，而且非常非常有效。

10.注意背景

排列镜头时，请特别注意背景。根据我的经验，由与蜻蜓形成鲜明对比的颜色或色调构成的整洁背景会产生充满冲击力的镜头。

然而，一些豆娘会降落在靠近水面的植被中，使得干净的背景几乎不可能。较大的光圈有助于模糊任何分散注意力的元素；如前所述，如果您可以纵向捕获豆娘，则效果很好。更大的光圈还有助于在背景中产生散景（来自离焦高光的光圈），这可能会很华丽（尽管这确实取决于您的个人品味！）。

如果可能，在选择拍摄地点时，请尝试将拍摄对象放置在远离背景中任何可能分散注意力的植被的位置。移动栖息处，或者随身携带自己的栖息处，可能会有所帮助！

11.考虑构图

蜻蜓在构图方面提供了一系列选择。并不总是需要将整个蜻蜓包含在框架中。如果距离足够近，您可以尝试对眼睛或部分翅膀进行极端特写。

或者，您可以在蜻蜓周围捕捉蜻蜓。例如，虹彩蓑羽蝶栖息在河岸低处时看起来很棒。这对于稍大的蜻蜓尤其有效，并且由于昆虫不必主导图像，因此可能不需要专用的微距镜头。

12.尝试捕捉一些行为

蜻蜓休息时看起来很棒，但如果可以的话，尝试捕捉它们的一些行为以获得独特的镜头。

例如，豆娘交配可以形成看起来有点像心形的形状，这可以形成令人愉悦的图像。或者，如果您愿意接受挑战，您可以尝试射击飞行中的蜻蜓。

为此，我建议使用 300-400mm 范围内带有延长管的长焦镜头。花几分钟观察蜻蜓如何移动（它们经常重复遵循相同的路径！）。观察到它们飞行后，将注意力集中在飞行路径上的一个点上，等待蜻蜓进入画面。

这种类型的拍摄有运气的成分。我尝试过很多不同的场合，有时蜻蜓会看似随机地改变它的飞行模式。但不要放弃；请记住，耐心是所有野生动物摄影的关键！享受观察和拍摄这些神奇昆虫的过程。

蜻蜓摄影：最后的话

好吧，你已经有了：

大量提示和技巧可帮助您拍摄蜻蜓的精彩照片。

请记住，坚持不懈可以走很长的路 - 如果您坚持下去并遵循我上面分享的提示，您一定会创作出一些令人惊叹的照片。

如何创建环境肖像（提示和示例）一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

本文于 2023 年 11 月更新，由 Darren Rowse、 Kevin Landwer-Johan 、 Kav Dadfar 、 Rick Berk 、 Post Production Pye和 Jaymes Dempsey 贡献。

与仅关注拍摄对象的标准肖像不同，环境肖像展示了人物及其周围环境。这些图像通常具有独特的吸引力，因为它们提供了了解拍摄对象世界的窗口，但我们要明确一点：获得引人注目的环境肖像并不是在公园散步。

您需要兼顾各种元素，例如设置、灯光和构图。这是一种复杂的平衡行为，如果处理得当，就能拍出有故事性的有力照片。

这就是本终极指南的全部内容。我将解释环境人像摄影的所有基础知识，然后提供必要的提示和技术来帮助您开始拍摄有意义的环境人像。

让我们开始吧。

什么是环境人像？

简单地说，环境肖像是指不仅仅包括拍摄对象的肖像。这个想法是在更广泛的背景下捕捉一个人，让人们了解他们的生活、个性或职业。

环境人像摄影不涉及拍摄日常头像或头部和肩部图像。相反，摄影师通常使用更宽的镜头来显示拍摄对象以及附近的元素。

请注意，环境肖像并不总是摆出姿势，但它总是涉及拍摄对象的意识。换句话说，你的拍摄对象知道他们正在被拍照。虽然无计划的偷拍摄影有其自身的魅力，但环境肖像通常涉及摄影师和拍摄对象之间的一定程度的互动。如果您的拍摄对象没有意识到他们正在被拍照，那么您可能正在冒险进入街头摄影领域。

环境肖像的背景可以是多种多样的——您选择的背景，无论是熙熙攘攘的市场还是宁静的海滩，都会显着影响图像的情绪和意义。一些摄影师喜欢在自然栖息地捕捉拍摄对象：厨房里的厨师、工作室里的音乐家或山路上的徒步旅行者。关键是场景应该丰富你想要讲述的故事，而不是分散注意力。

为什么环境人像有如此强大的力量？

有没有想过为什么有些肖像只是对你说话？许多最好的肖像画不仅仅展示一个人——它们讲述一个故事，或者至少提供对这个主题是谁的洞察。环境肖像擅长讲故事。因为它们包含了拍摄对象的周围环境，所以这些肖像添加了有关该拍摄对象的额外信息层。你看到的不仅仅是一张脸，还有一个人在某个地方，正在做某事或者是更大场景的一部分。

这些额外的上下文有助于观看者更好地理解主题。在排练场拍摄的音乐家，周围都是乐器，可以告诉您更多有关他们的奉献精神和热情的信息。同样，在教室里拍摄的老师，即使没有学生，也会给人一种使命感。

环境肖像的力量还在于其真实性。因为您融入了现实世界的元素，所以这些照片感觉很接地气。您不只是捕捉一张脸；而是捕捉一张脸。你正在捕捉那张脸和周围环境之间的关系。

美丽环境人像摄影的技巧

拍摄华丽的环境肖像似乎很困难，但实际上有一些简单的方法可以改善您的结果，首先：

1. 花时间了解你的主题

在选择地点并开始拍摄之前，请花一些时间了解您的拍摄对象。

了解他们的时间都花在哪里、他们的生活节奏如何以及他们的行为方式。

这不仅可以帮助您找到合适的位置，还可以帮助您了解可能适合该会话的拍摄风格。

另外，您将开始帮助您的拍摄对象放松的过程！如果可以的话，你甚至可能想陪你的拍摄对象去一些可能的地点；这样，您就可以了解该位置是否适合他们，以及他们在那里的行为和互动方式。

2. 让你的主题说话

现在您已经对拍摄对象、他们喜欢做什么以及喜欢在哪里做有了一些了解，是时候将相机对准他们了。

这可能是拍摄的“成败”点。如果你的拍摄对象在镜头前感到不舒服，它就会在图像中表现出来——除非你找到一种方法让他们放松。

幸运的是，让他们放松的最简单方法之一就是开始对话。通过询问他们自己的情况，让他们忘记您正在给他们拍照。让他们谈论地点、他们的爱好、他们的家庭、他们的工作——任何能让他们把注意力从面前的镜头上转移开的事情。

对于下面的肖像，我的拍摄对象是住在附近的纽约人。这是一次私人辅导课后的即兴课程，她不愿意让我把镜头对准她。她想自己学摄影，所以我在玩笑中加入了一节课，很快她就只是在谈论摄影，而忘记了我正在拍照！

3.选择合适的地点

有时，某个地点会选择您，但在其他情况下，您在做出选择时需要经过深思熟虑且有目的。这可能需要大量的搜索。

理想情况下，您想要找到一个位置：

  • 说了一些关于你的主题的事情。毕竟，这就是这种摄影风格的意义所在。
  • 增加拍摄的趣味性。正如我在之前的教程中所写的，图像中的每个元素都可以增加或削弱整体外观。您放置主题的环境需要提供背景和兴趣，而又不会压倒构图。
  • 不主导投篮。有时，位置可能会在图像中占据主导地位，从而分散观看者对主要焦点（即主题）的注意力。因此，请尽量避免杂乱的背景（和前景）和太亮的颜色等。请记住，您可以通过巧妙的裁剪、 景深和主题放置来消除干扰。

4.尝试讲述你的拍摄对象的故事

一旦你们聊了一段时间，或者至少敏锐地观察了，就讲述他们的故事。

专注于最能直观地传达此人的信息、他们在哪里以及他们在做什么。这就是环境肖像的全部本质。

他们是一个安静、内向的人吗？或者他们是一个大声喧闹的角色？有些人一到镜头前就变了。

如果他们一直在热烈地聊天，当你把相机对准他们时他们就僵住了，那么你的工作就是帮助他们放松。冻结不是他们本来的样子。

5.使用道具，但要保持自然

环境人像中道具的使用是一把双刃剑。虽然它们可以增加价值，但也很容易分散注意力。诀窍在于选择能够增强而不是削弱图像的道具。想象一下你正在拍摄一位作家；桌上的笔和笔记本可以增加一层背景和意义。

服装也可以作为一种道具。你的拍摄对象的穿着应该与环境和谐。如果你要拍摄渔民，他们穿着工作服和橡胶靴是有意义的。企业高管？西装或正装都符合要求。这个想法是避免任何感觉不合适或强迫的事情。

道具应该是环境或拍摄对象个性的自然延伸。在厨房里拍摄的厨师手里可能拿着一把木勺，但是一把中世纪的剑呢？没那么多。同样的原则也适用于不太有形的道具，例如灯光甚至宠物。如果您在家中拍摄一家人的照片，一只徘徊在画面中的宠物猫可能会是一个可爱的补充。

要有辨别力。您引入的每个元素都应该服务于图像的总体叙述。经验法则是：如果道具没有增加主题的故事或在背景中看起来不协调，那么最好将其排除在外！

6.注意干扰

当您扩大框架以包含更多环境时，请务必小心。包含太多内容可能会引入分散注意力的元素，从而将注意力从主题上转移开。您最不想看到的就是杂散的电线杆、放置奇怪的垃圾桶或华丽的广告牌成为您图像中无意的焦点。

注意周围环境至关重要。检查设置中是否有任何可能与您想要的整体情绪或基调相冲突的内容。有时，即使是背景中的一块鲜艳的色彩或明亮的光源也会破坏构图。

简单的修复通常需要进行细微的调整。让你的拍摄对象向右或向左移动几英尺可以让世界变得不同。同样，您可以改变自己的位置或角度，以排除画面中的干扰。这些小调整可以将观众的注意力重新集中在它所属的地方：你的主题。

7.用光工作

光线可以决定任何照片的成败，环境人像也不例外。光的来源和质量可以极大地影响图像的情绪、纹理和整体效果。无论您面对的是正午的刺眼阳光，还是阴天下午柔和的漫射光线，我们的目标都是充分利用它。

强烈、对比强烈的光线可以产生浓重的阴影，为你的拍摄对象及其环境增添一层戏剧性。虽然这可能适用于某些场景，但并不总是令人满意的效果。另一方面，在阴天，阴天就像一个天然的柔光箱，提供迷人的光线，均匀地照亮你的拍摄对象。

黄金时段，即日出后或日落前不久的时期，提供了另一个照明机会。这些时候温暖的定向光可以为您的图像增添三维感。它可以呈现出纹理并投射出长而柔和的阴影——所以我强烈建议您一有机会就使用它。

8.考虑修改光线

我尝试尽可能少地使用环境肖像的设备并使用自然光。然而，有时光线并不理想（例如，极其刺眼）——在这种情况下，您需要以某种方式对其进行修改。

这可以很简单，只需在战略位置添加反射器或使用柔光箱或雨伞设置闪光灯即可。这完全取决于可用的光线和您想要​​的外观。我一直尝试做的一件事就是让光线看起来尽可能自然。

下一张照片是一张商业肖像，但我的客户想要的不仅仅是一张简单的头像。这是在当天晚些时候拍摄的，这意味着我必须自己创造灯光。她希望她的团队在后台工作（因为她想表明，当你和她一起工作时，她有整个团队支持她）。我使用热靴灯通过将其从白墙和天花板上反射来照亮背景。然后我使用由 28 英寸柔光箱改造的第二个热靴灯来照亮我的客户。我调整了照明强度，使背景光与主光的比例为 2:1。

9. 考虑拍摄主题的姿势

并非每张环境肖像都需要精心摆姿势。然而，一些精心设计的姿势会对最终结果产生很大的影响。

因此，不要害怕引导拍摄对象以适合环境的方式坐下、站立或行动。有些姿势可能看起来有点不自然和戏剧性，但通常这些故意摆出的姿势的照片更有趣，并给你的摄影带来一种风格感。

在环境摄影中，拍摄对象的面部表情也非常重要，您应该考虑它如何与整体场景相契合。

例如，如果您在正式环境中拍摄，拍摄对象时可能不适合拍摄一个大而俗气的微笑；您可能更喜欢阴沉或更严肃的外观。

最后，将其混合起来看看什么有效，什么无效！

10.考虑捕捉一系列图像

如果一张环境肖像可以讲述一个故事，想象一下一系列的环境肖像可以做什么。这种方法可以让您更深入地了解拍摄对象的生活，更全面地了解他们是谁以及对他们来说重要的事情。拍摄一系列照片可以确保对拍摄对象进行细致入微的呈现，这是单靠一张照片可能无法捕捉到的。

例如，您可以全天关注您的主题。在工作中记录它们，在家里安静的时刻捕捉它们，甚至在爱好或社交活动中捕捉它们。这种方法可以产生一个引人入胜的系列，充分讲述拍摄对象的生活和激情。

另一个想法是长时间在不同的环境下拍摄你的拍摄对象。这不仅在不同的背景下展示主题，而且还提供了捕捉变化和成长的可能性。这可能是一种令人信服的方式，可以探索诸如衰老，职业发展甚至重大生活事件的影响之类的主题。

11.故意选择您的相机设置（尤其是您的光圈！）

没有正确或错误的方法来为环境肖像设置相机。这将完全取决于您追求的效果以及拍摄方案。

您可能会发现，以较小的光圈拍摄（即，较大的f数字）是合适的，因为它将有助于保持前景和背景的焦点。

我通常会拍摄具有更大焦距的环境肖像，以使环境在镜头中的突出性。 （有关为环境摄影选择镜头的更多信息，请参见下文！）

当然，这并不意味着您不能用更长的镜头或较大的光圈和浅水深度射击。最后，一切都会发生！

12.在室内拍照时，请提高您的ISO

通常，您应该在拍照时保持尽可能低的ISO。

但是，在诸如市场和内部建筑物之类的弱光条件下，您可能必须将其提高，以确保您可以以足够快的快门速度捕获照片，以进行锋利的拍摄。

我的建议：您应该在不同的ISO设置上测试相机，以了解它将产生的可接受噪音，以便当您在现场时，您不会超越它！

13.知道你的相机

如果他们看到的只是您的头顶，当您凝视着相机时，您的主题可能会失去兴趣。

预设相机，以便您知道设置将正确。尽快执行此操作，因此您将有时间专注于与您的主题和其他重要事情进行沟通。

14.使用实时视图

这与上面的项目一起播放。当您将相机抬高到您的眼睛，等待图像拍摄时，大多数人都会紧张。有些人甚至可能无意中闭上了眼睛，期待闪烁。如果您可以在相机上使用Live View，则可以将其从脸部脱离。您的主题将看着您，而不是在相机上，并且不一定会期望您按下快门按钮。这与具有铰接式屏幕的相机特别有效。使用远程释放触发相机，也可以将相机安装在三脚架上也可能有所帮助。

15.仔细选择镜头

展示周围环境很重要。因此，在您工作时与您的主题进行沟通。

如果您的相机上有远摄镜头，则必须将自己的镜头放置很长一段路，以包括足够的环境。

有了中等到宽的镜头，您可以足够近，还包括更多设置。我喜欢在全帧车身上使用35毫米f/1.4镜头进行环境肖像。它使我足够靠近以舒适地交谈，并且仍然显示出相当数量的背景。

如果您使用的镜头远远超过35mm，请小心，因为您有扭曲主题的风险。

16.时间你的镜头

在环境肖像中，时机就是一切。您想以对他们真实的状态抓住您的主题 - 如果他们与周围环境互动，那就更好了。这种和谐可以传达有关人和他们所在的地方的深刻信息。

时刻做好准备。在快门按钮上准备好手指。并认为有价值的形象不仅涉及对象的面部表情或肢体语言。这可能是一个短暂的时刻，他们与环境互动以完美封装与环境的关系的方式进行互动。例如，一位音乐家以歌曲的节奏迷失，厨师沉浸在香料的感官中，或者在公园里玩耍时孩子的纯粹喜悦。

17.捕获多个人互动

环境肖像不仅限于个人主题。包括多个人可以在您的照片中添加另一层深度和情感。但这是关键：当更多的人在框架中时，关注他们的互动至关重要。

两次或更多人互动的时机镜头可以讲述一个引人入胜的故事。这可能是一对夫妇分享一个温柔的时刻，同事沉浸在一个项目中，甚至是一个享受简单饭的家庭。尝试捕获感觉有机而不是上演的真正互动。

有了更多的主题，您还必须对构图特别谨慎。他们的定位应与整个镜头进行补充，如果您可以以指导观众眼睛的照片来安排它们，它将增强视觉流程。每个人理想地都应为您要传达的整体叙述做出贡献，以确保凝聚力和有影响力的照​​片。

底线：包括单个肖像镜头中的多个人要具有挑战性地完成，但在做得正确时会非常有意义！

18.写好字幕

良好的标题将提供您可能无法在照片中清楚传达的添加细节。信息性的标题有助于通过进一步刺激人们的想象力来保持人们的兴趣。

提供有关该人的更多信息。这是在拍照时与他们互动的另一个好理由。

如果您不清楚写什么，请搜索互联网。

19.不要害怕射击

确实，环境肖像通常意味着显示主题周围的某些区域 - 环境 - 您可以接近并仍然显示主体的角色。掌握主题的爱好元素，并向他们展示参加爱好。如果它们是模型构建器，则可以对它们涂上胶水或组装碎片进行严格的镜头。这是您创造性的机会，尝试不同的角度，专注于他们个性和性格的不同方面。强调以讨人喜欢的方式突出的功能，如果这是目标。找出是什么使您的相机前面的人与众不同，然后捕获它！

这是与桥前面的镜头一样的女孩。她现在也是一名摄影师，但是那时她只是一个爱好者，想进一步了解她的相机。我使用了我要获得的美丽日落灯，并将反射器设置为相机，然后将光线弹回她的脸上。我想让她从相机后面窥视，说明她正在摄影。

20.记住要应用一些编辑！

如果您用RAW拍摄环境肖像，我强烈建议您这样做！ - 然后，您需要添加一些较小的调整，以确保您的照片与您看到的场景紧密匹配。

增强对比度，增加了锐化，恢复阴影并突出显示细节，稍微加强饱和度 - 这些都是创造更自然结果的有效方法。

一旦完成，您总是可以享受一些创意编辑，将您的肖像提升到一个新的水平。您可以添加一个小插图来专注于主题的脸部，可以减少天空中的曝光，以获得一些添加的戏剧，甚至可以使用躲避和燃烧来为场景增加一些三维的效果！

This article was updated in November 2023 with contributions from Chris Folsom, Sarah, Misho Baranovic, Sandra Roussy , Jaymes Dempsey , and Lori Peterson .

Struggling to take beautiful photos using only your iPhone? It's not as hard as you might think.

Most people don't realize it, but iPhones contain surprisingly capable cameras – cameras that become more powerful with every new release. In the hands of a skilled photographer, an iPhone can be an effective way to capture stunning landscape shots , portrait photos, street images, and much more. Often, these iPhone photos are effectively indistinguishable from photos taken with high-end DSLRs and mirrorless models .

Of course, capturing good iPhone photos does require some careful techniques, and that's what I share in this article: Key lessons I've learned since picking up my iPhone camera. Once you know these basic iPhone photography tips and techniques, I guarantee that your images will improve in leaps and bounds.

So without further ado, let's get started!

Powerful tips for beautiful iPhone photos

Let's kick things off with 16 effective tips to get you using your iPhone like an expert – including advice for choosing iPhone photography apps, techniques for improving image sharpness, and easy approaches to enhance your iPhone compositions.

1. Hold your iPhone like a camera

When I first started taking iPhone photos, I held my phone with just one hand.那是个错误。

One-handing your phone works great for casual, everyday activities, but when you're shooting photos, you want to keep your phone as steady as possible. In other words, you should generally use two hands.

Try cupping your hands together, kind of like you'd hold a small point-and-shoot camera. Then let your right thumb hover over the shutter button. When you're ready to snap a photo, just press down gently with that thumb while keeping your hands rock-solid.

You can use a similar technique when holding your iPhone horizontally (ie, when capturing a landscape-orientation shot). Let your left hand support your right hand, and keep your thumb in position to fire that shutter.

Note that you should never jab at the shutter button, nor should you stretch your thumb so it's in position. Make sure everything feels natural and comfortable; that way, you'll get crisp, highly detailed results.

Also, keep your elbows tucked in and your iPhone screen close to your body. When I first started iPhoneography, I held my phone out at a ridiculous angle, which created a lot of camera shake (and as a consequence, a lot of image blur). Now I hold the phone in front of my chest or face, and I “look” through the screen as if I were using a conventional camera model.

2. Zoom with your feet

There are two types of iPhone camera zooms: Optical zoom and digital zoom.

Optical zoom is created by camera optics; this is the kind of zoom at work when you switch from your wide lens to your telephoto lens or your ultra-wide lens to your wide lens.

Digital zoom, however, is created by cropping; your iPhone simply deletes pixels to create a “zoom” effect.

As you probably realize, there's nothing wrong with using optical zoom. If your iPhone has multiple lenses, then you should absolutely use them as required. Switch to a telephoto lens when you need to get close, and switch to an ultra-wide lens when you need to capture a wide frame.

But digital zoom is problematic. It won't actually get you any closer to your subject. Instead, it'll just damage your images.

So when you feel the urge to use your iPhone's digital zoom option, zoom with your feet. Don't sacrifice any pixels. Simply move closer to your subject!

3. Shoot the same subject a few times

One of the great things about iPhone photography is that it allows a lot of attempts – and a lot of mistakes. So take advantage! Instead of capturing one shot of each subject, take multiple photos of the same thing, then pick out your best shots later.

I don't mean that you should constantly fire off photos left and right. You don't want to end up with thousands of files, all featuring the same boring scene. But it does pay to capture subjects from a few different angles, using a few different compositional approaches, etc. That way, you can ensure that you get the best possible result (and you can let yourself be as creative as possible).

I love shooting at the beach with my phone. I'll take tons of images on a walk, check them out when I get home, then delete all the bad ones when I get home (that way, I don't run out of storage space!).

Pro tip: Don't delete any files when you're out shooting. Certain photos might seem bad at the time, but once you're back at home, you may find that some of your “worst” images actually turn out to be your best!

4. Use the rule of thirds

The rule of thirds is a popular composition guideline in photography, and for good reason: it ensures that photos feel balanced and that the viewer's eye flows easily across the scene.

The idea is to divide each frame into thirds (both horizontally and vertically), then position key image elements along these “rule of thirds” gridlines. So if you were photographing a landscape, you would position the horizon along the upper or lower third gridline.

And if you were photographing a person on the street, you would position their body along the right or left gridline.

You don't have to use the rule of thirds all the time, but it often works great – whether you're shooting with an iPhone or a fancy professional setup!

5. Move in close

Sometimes a small detail can take a photograph from good to wow, so don't be afraid to really get in close with your iPhone.

In fact, highlighting specific details is a great way to capture shots that show the viewer something different about the world – a new texture, a relationship between objects that are easily overlooked, a small area of beauty.

And iPhones are surprisingly good at focusing up close, so don't be shy: experiment with objects, plants, or even pets around the house!

6. Pay attention to the light

Poorly chosen light can ruin any photo, whether you're working with an iPhone camera or a $5000 DSLR. On the flip side, if you can master light, you'll be an unstoppable photographer.

So pay careful attention to the light at all times. Observe the light's quality, volume, and direction. Recognize how each type of light will affect your images.

Early morning and late afternoon offer golden-hour light , which looks soft, warm, and breathtakingly beautiful. You should experiment with different lighting angles, too; sidelighting will add three-dimensionality and emphasize texture, while front lighting will offer lots of detail but keep your subject looking flat.

I'd recommend that you avoid shooting in the middle of the day (unless it's cloudy). Midday sun tends to be pretty harsh, and it'll make it very difficult to retain details in the shadows and highlights of your photos.

But while brighter light is good for capturing detail, don't skip those nighttime photo opportunities. The newest iPhones offer surprisingly impressive low-light capabilities; you can even use them to capture the stars!

7. Seek out contrast and shadows

8. Capture test compositions while scouting

Even if you're a dedicated DSLR or mirrorless camera user, the iPhone can be an invaluable tool in your photography arsenal, particularly for scouting potential shots. Imagine you're out exploring or even just walking through your neighborhood and stumble upon a scene that catches your eye.

With your iPhone, you can quickly capture test shots, experimenting with different angles and compositions. This approach offers a no-pressure way to visualize potential photos without the need for a full camera setup. These iPhone snapshots serve as visual notes, helping you plan for a future session with more specialized equipment. It's a practice that can significantly enhance your preparedness and creativity, turning spontaneous discoveries into well-planned photo shoots.

9. Try your iPhone's alternative shutter buttons

Every iPhone offers a main shutter button: That big white target right at the bottom of the screen. But did you know that you can actually trigger your iPhone's shutter in several different ways?

For instance, you can take a photo by pressing the volume keys (ie, the volume up and volume down buttons). You can also take a photo by pressing the external volume buttons on headphone wires (though this only works on certain headphone models, so you'll need to test it out yourself).

Either of the latter options is hugely useful if you want to take photos discreetly. For instance, if you're capturing candid street portraits, you can move close to your subject, then trigger the shutter using your headphones. As long as you pretend to be occupied with something else, your subject will never realize what you're doing.

One more tip: If you want to fire your iPhone shutter from a distance, make sure that you turn on Voice Control, open the camera app, and say, “Turn up the volume.” Your iPhone will instantly take a photo!很酷，对吧？

10. Capture some panoramas

One of the most striking features of the iPhone camera is its ability to shoot expansive panoramas. With Pano mode, you can easily capture breathtaking landscapes, sprawling cityscapes, or any scene that requires a wider view.

To create a panoramic photo, switch your iPhone camera to Pano mode, hit the shutter button, and slowly pan your phone across the scene as directed on-screen.

The result is often a stunning, wide-angle view that can rival professional-grade cameras. This feature isn't just for landscapes; it can add a dramatic effect to architecture, travel scenes, cityscapes, and more!

11. Download different camera apps

The native iPhone camera app is nice, but you can gain far more control via various dedicated camera apps (many of which are free!).

Apps like Lightroom Mobile and Photon will let you adjust various settings manually, including shutter speed and ISO . That way, you can ensure you're getting the best possible image quality, plus you can create all sorts of creative effects. Obviously, you shouldn't jump into fully manual iPhone apps until you're ready – but it's definitely worth playing around and seeing what you think.

I'd also encourage you to check out various creative iPhone photography apps. 13. Shoot from different angles

iPhones are small and light – which means it's far easier to get down low or climb up high when doing iPhone photography (versus shooting with a heavy DSLR).

So take advantage of that capability. While it's tempting to just shoot from standing height, I encourage you to experiment with many different angles. Crouch low to the ground and see if you can include a compelling object or line in the foreground. Then raise your iPhone high above your head for a top-down shot (or see if you can find some stairs for an even higher vantage point).

In my experience, testing out different angles is a lot of fun – and it can create dramatically different images. The more you seek out different angles, the more you'll start to realize the incredible variety of options you have as an iPhone photographer.

14. Clean your iPhone lens

iPhones get stashed in pockets, purses, backpacks, car cubbies, and drawers. They suffer rain, snow, mud, dust, oily fingers, and dirt.

And yet – somehow! – we iPhone photographers always forget to clean our lenses.

When I first started doing iPhone photography, I didn't clean the lens for months. Then, when I finally gave it a little wipe, it made such a difference. A clean lens will capture sharper, higher-contrast images, plus it just feels a lot better to shoot with pristine glass.

So get in the habit of regularly cleaning your iPhone camera lenses. (If your iPhone uses multiple lenses, be sure to clean them all!) Technically, you can clean off the glass with some tissue, a cloth, or even your shirt, but I'd encourage you to purchase a microfiber cloth or some lens wipes, which will get rid of grime without damaging the lens elements.

15. Simplify your compositions

Here's another piece of iPhone photography composition advice.

Keep your images as simple as possible.

If possible, identify one part of your image to highlight: a person, a building, or even a detail. Then try to remove everything that could possibly draw attention away from this element. (You can do this in various ways; try changing your angle, taking a few steps forward, or switching to your telephoto lens.)

That way, when a viewer is confronted by your photo, they'll know exactly where to look!

Want to capture some magical levitation images? Levitation photography might seem difficult, but it's actually pretty easy. As long as you know the simple, step-by-step process, you can create beautiful levitation photos of your very own, the kind that shock viewers and look consistently incredible .

Now, I'll be the first to admit it: When I started out with levitation photography, I struggled. But over time, I made tweaks and improvements to my approach and capturing good levitation shots got easier and easier. Today, I'm ready to share that approach with you – so you can skip past my mistakes and start making great shots right away.

Below, I share everything you need to know to conduct successful levitation photoshoots, including:

  • All the gear you do (and don't) need
  • How to choose the right angle and composition for a stunning effect
  • How to process your levitation shots for the best results
  • 多得多！

Ready to become a levitation master? Then let's dive right in.

What is levitation photography?

Levitation photography refers to images depicting subjects that appear to be floating, or levitating, in the air.

Levitation images are designed to look strange, spooky, or just generally surreal. The goal is not to display reality, but to instead create mindbending compositions that perplex the viewer.

While you can technically create a levitation shot by asking your subject to jump (or by throwing your subject into the air) and firing the shutter at the right time, most levitation photos are created with some post-production trickery, which I explain in depth稍后的。

What subjects work best for levitation photography?

Unless you want to spend dozens of hours in Photoshop carefully removing, compositing , and cloning different subjects, I'd recommend selecting levitation subjects that are capable of standing or lying on a stool.

Most levitation photographers work with portrait subjects; after all, you can instruct people to stand in the right place, to balance atop different objects, and so on.

Note that you can create interesting arrangements with multiple portrait subjects. For instance, you might do a group levitation shot, where an entire family or wedding party appears to be floating above the ground. Or you might give one subject the “non-magic” role and have them stand on the grass while other subjects float around the scene.

That said, if you don't have any portrait subjects or you simply want to create more original photos, you can certainly have fun levitating inanimate objects. You might levitate:

  • 沙发
  • 椅子
  • 扫帚
  • 食物
  • 电脑
  • Soap bottles
  • 相机

In particular, levitation can be a potent technique for professional food or product photography . By levitating items (or pieces) of food, you can create a very modern, fresh look. And by levitating products, you can create a sense of energy and vitality that complements images of shoes, portable technology, and more.

How to do levitation photography: the basics

Levitation photoshoots aren't especially complex, but they do take some gear and know-how. In this section, I share my step-by-step process for creating high-quality levitation images.

Step 1: Gather your equipment

To produce a successful levitation image, you need:

  • A camera and lens (with manual focusing capabilities )
  • 三脚架
  • A willing model (or inanimate object)
  • Something to position your subject on, such as a stool, a chair, or a ladder

Step 2: Head to your location

Many photographers do levitation photoshoots in remote locations. But while isolated meadows and dark forests will certainly contribute to the spooky atmosphere, you can also take great levitation shots in your backyard, in a local park, or even indoors.

Just make sure you choose your location carefully. You need an area that will be relatively free of passersby (you don't want to spend time cloning people out of the background). And the more room you have to shoot, the better.

If you're working with a model, I'd recommend arriving on location a few minutes in advance. That way, you can mount your camera on a tripod, consider different shooting angles, and select your exposure settings before your subject arrives.

Step 3: Photograph the scene with your subject on a perch

Levitation photography relies on two fundamental images:

  1. A shot of your subject sitting, standing, or lying on a perch (eg, a stool).
  2. A shot of the scene without the subject and without the perch.

The order in which you take the two shots technically doesn't matter, but it's much easier to compose the shot with the subject first, then capture the background shot later on.

So set up your first shot. Make sure your camera is carefully positioned on the tripod. If you're working with a portrait subject, ask them to perch on the stool and carefully direct them in a levitation-esque pose. If you're working with an inanimate object, position it as you prefer.

Switch your camera to manual focus, then adjust the focus until your main subject is tack-sharp. Set the exposure using Manual mode .

Take your first image. Check the result on the back of your camera, and make sure that you've nailed the focus and exposure.

Step 4: Photograph the scene without your subject

Next, remove everything from the scene: your stools, your subjects, and any additional props .

Without changing the exposure or the focus, take a second image. This should feature only the background (but the point of focus should remain on the foreground!).

Step 5: Blend the images

At this point, you have the raw components of your levitation shot. Now it's time to combine the two images to create a realistic final composition.

Open your two files in a basic editing program such as Lightroom, and make sure the colors and exposures match perfectly. If you notice any differences between the images, spend some time making adjustments to the exposure and/or white balance . (You can also apply general edits to both files, though make sure you keep all edits consistent across the two shots!)

Next, open the files as layers in Adobe Photoshop. Make sure the empty background image is on the bottom of the layer stack.

Click on the upper layer (with your subject) and create a mask . Initially, the mask will be white, so your image will remain unaltered. But select a Brush , make sure the color is black, and then paint over the subject's supporting elements (ie, the stool). Watch as the stool disappears, leaving behind the untouched background…

…and your subject starts to levitate!

Finally, merge the layers, and export the final image as a JPEG for sharing.

Levitation photography tips

Want to level up your levitation photos? In this section, I share a few quick tips to enhance your results.

1. Shoot on a cloudy day

Yes, it's possible to create beautiful levitation photos in bright sunlight. But it's a major pain.

You see, if you work with lots of sun, then your subject and your subject's perch will create shadows. When you go to merge the two images in Photoshop, you'll need to spend time correcting the subject's shadow and removing the perch's shadow, which isn't fun and can take an annoying amount of time.

So unless you're a Photoshop expert, I'd really recommend doing your levitation photoshoots on cloudy days or in the shade. That way, you can avoid difficult shadows and get realistic results straight out of the camera.

2. Tell your model what to wear

In my experience, clothing can make or break a levitation image. Therefore, it's essential that you guide your model in their wardrobe choices. Here are a few handy items of advice:

  • Solid-color clothing is best. Prints and patterns can make it difficult to clone out certain parts of clothing or liquify fabric.
  • Avoid jackets and sweaters. Anytime the model lies upside down or sideways, the garment should technically be hanging down – but if the model is actually lying on a stool, the jacket won't hang naturally, and the result will be less realistic.
  • If you're going for a feminine levitation shot, long dresses, skirts, and other flowy fabrics can give you a very cool look.

3. Shoot from a low angle

If you use a wide-angle lens and get down low, your subject will appear to float higher in the air. (Conversely, if you shoot down on your subject from above, they'll appear closer to the ground.)

In general, it's better to get low, but be mindful of your angle. If you get lower than the perch your model is standing or lying on, the perch's material will start to block the model's body, and you'll be unable to realistically remove the perch in Photoshop.

It's safest to shoot in line with the top of the perch (and you can also make sure your model is sitting at the very front of the perch to lessen the risk of issues).

If you're looking for a more visual tutorial, I highly recommend the video below! Not everyone captures levitation shots the same way, and the video is geared toward product and still-life photographers, but it's definitely worth a watch.

The levitation photography approach

  1. Choose an object that you want to make float.
  2. Expose for your subject (this will vary depending on the lighting!).
  3. The trick is to take one photo holding your subject with your left hand, and then a second photo holding your subject with your right hand.
  4. Make sure you choose Grids ON in your camera menu.
  5. Line up the subject in the same spot for each shot (that's where the grid comes in handy!).
  6. Use manual focus for each shot; you want the focus to be the same for each photo.
  7. Hold your subject with one hand, focus, and take the first photo.
  8. While still holding your subject, grab the opposite side with your other hand (keeping it in the same position). Let go with the first hand, and without moving, take the second photo. Try this as many times as necessary to get a good result.
  9. Edit your best photos in Lightroom (or the editing program of your choice).
  10. Once you determine the two shots you want to combine, send the image over to Photoshop.
  11. Select the image with your subject held in your left hand. Double-click the layer in the Layer Palette to make it editable.

  17. Next, we want to take the top layer and delete parts we don't want.
  18. Add a layer mask to the top layer and select your Brush Tool (make sure the brush is soft!).
  19. Change the foreground color in your toolbar to black; that way, you can paint out areas of the layer mask.
  20. Paint out the areas you don't want. Start with a larger brush, then make the brush smaller and continue to paint out areas you don't need.
  21. Check all your lines around your image to ensure they line up.

What are ultra-wide angle lenses?

Ultra-wide angle lenses are extreme versions of wide-angle lenses . Instead of producing a field of view that's subtly wider than the human eye, they offer a field of view that's far wider. They create a beautifully expansive effect:

Notice how, in the photo above, I've managed to capture over half of the room. That's the power of an ultra-wide lens!

So what focal lengths correspond to ultra-wides?

Well, as you may already be aware, a 50mm lens (on a full-frame camera) closely approximates the field of view of the human eye. And wide-angle lenses feature smaller focal lengths, generally from around 24mm to 49mm.

Therefore, ultra-wide angle lenses have focal lengths that are wider than 24mm. A 10-20mm lens, for instance, is an ultra-wide zoom, while a 14mm lens is an ultra-wide prime.

(Note that these focal lengths are approximate; there's no single agreed-upon set of focal lengths for wide and ultra-wide lenses.)

Take a look at this image, which is taken with a wide-angle (28mm) lens:

Then see how an ultra-wide focal length (11mm) widens the scene even further:

So while wide-angle lenses and ultra-wide angle lenses have a broad field of view, the ultra-wide effect is much more extreme.

When should you use an ultra-wide angle lens?

Ultra-wide lenses are hugely helpful, but you don't want to use them all the time. For instance, trying to shoot a distant bird with an ultra-wide lens will get you nothing but a landscape and a distant blotch of feathers.

On the other hand, you can use ultra-wide lenses to capture entire scenes in a single shot. For instance, you can photograph an entire city skyline from end to end. Or you can photograph a beautiful mountain scene and include a foreground, a middleground, and plenty of mountain background.

Here are a few genres where ultra-wides are useful:

  • Landscape photography
  • Architectural photography
  • Real-estate photography
  • Cityscape photography

1. Ultra-wides immerse the viewer in the scene

Ultra-wide angle lenses draw the viewer into the situation.

They surround the viewer with the scene, and for that reason, the resulting shots feel stunningly real and full of detail.

And ultra-wides don't just immerse the viewer in the scene; they immerse you , the photographer, which can be a wild experience.

As you shoot, you'll feel like the entire scene is wrapping around your head. You'll be pulled into the action, which is a great place to be!

2. Ultra-wides help you avoid perspective distortion

Perspective distortion causes vertical lines to converge, and it'll even make buildings look like they're falling backward. While it's possible to fix distortion in post-processing, it's much more efficient to avoid it in the first place – and ultra-wides can help you out.

You see, perspective distortion is produced when you tilt your camera downward or upward to photograph a scene. For instance, you might point your camera up to photograph a cathedral like this one:

And it's that movement – that tilt up – that results in distortion.

But ultra-wide lenses are so wide that you often don't need to tilt the camera when capturing a building. Instead, you can point the camera straight ahead and just… shoot . You'll avoid distortion, and you'll get a beautiful architectural image.

3. Ultra-wides reverse scale

Ultra-wide lenses tend to make objects that are close to the lens look enormous, while they make objects that are farther away look tiny. The wider the lens, the greater the effect!

(This is another consequence of perspective distortion, which I discussed in the previous section.)

5. Ultra-wides are great for reflection shots

6. Ultra-wides include so much detail

Every ultra-wide lens includes a huge field of view…

If you want to photograph a beach landscape, you won't just get the water and the sky. You'll get the sand, the rocks, the people on the beach, and maybe even your own feet.

And if you want to photograph a cathedral, you won't just get the artwork on the ceiling or the stained-glass windows in the distance. Instead, you'll get everything, from the ceiling and the pews to the windows and the walls. Ultra-wides are wide !

Tips for capturing beautiful ultra-wide angle photography

1. Pay attention to the distortion

The first thing you notice is the exaggerated perspective, the distorted edges, and the relationships between foreground and background objects that are stretched, sometimes unnaturally. Wide-angle scenes can contain many objects at different distances, which helps to draw the viewer in.

You'll also get a different perspective compared to other lenses. As a rule, you'll find yourself moving much closer to the subject, stepping right into the scene. Think of ultra-wide lenses as the opposite of tele lenses where you tend to back away from objects. Telephoto lenses tend to flatten the scene, ultra-wide angle lenses exaggerate it. This makes background objects appear further from foreground ones than they actually are.

Sometimes you don't want this effect, and then it's best to make sure your camera is perfectly level. You can correct perspective distortions in post-processing, but you'll end up with much smaller images by the time the edges are chopped off.

2. Focus manually

On ultra-wide lenses, the auto-focus also faces new challenges since objects just a few meters away can be quite small and hard for the AF to lock onto. Beyond the first few meters, ultra-wide lenses tend to take a guess at focus, and that doesn't help with sharpness – manual focus can often be a better way to go. The main thing is to decide on the visual centre, and focus on that.

3. Watch for flare

Flare is a real pain with ultra-wide lenses, blowing out highlights with little provocation. The broad field of view means you often have a source of bright light not far from the frame, and that's enough to do the damage. The best times to use these lenses are the magic hours of early morning and late afternoon, outside, or middle of the day inside.

4. Use a tripod whenever you can

By now, it should be pretty obvious that pointing and shooting is the wrong technique for ultra-wide photography. Shooting early or late in the day, or inside, and stopping down to f/11 or more, means using a tripod. Add manual focusing and we're back in the good old days of carefully composing each shot, following a set of rules. Not a bad idea for landscape and architecture photography, but not practical for action or street photography.

5. Avoid close-up portraits

Ultra-wides don't make good portrait lenses unless you're looking for cartoon-like comic effects. In close-ups, you can get plenty of distortion that exaggerates the bits in the foreground, like noses and foreheads. Looking to capture mesmerizing blue hour photography? I share everything you need to know for breathtaking results.

Photographers love the blue hour, not least because it provides velvety, stunning, ethereal light. But learning to take advantage of the blue hour for gorgeous portraits , landscapes , and cityscapes isn't always easy. It requires special settings, special gear, and careful consideration of artificial lighting.

Fortunately, I'm a veteran blue hour photographer, and I've developed plenty of tips and tricks that'll help you achieve amazing results. Below, I share everything you need to know, including:

  • What blue hour is
  • When blue hour occurs
  • The best settings for blue hour photography
  • Essential blue hour gear
  • 多得多！

By the time you're finished, you'll be ready to capture gorgeous blue hour shots like a pro, so let's dive right in!

What is the blue hour in photography?

The blue hour is the time just before sunrise and just after sunset when the sun is below the horizon and the sky (generally) turns a beautiful shade of blue. Blue-hour skies can also take on orange, yellow, purple, and pink hues.

Photographers love blue hour lighting thanks to its softness and lack of directionality; as a result, during the blue hour, subjects take on a sort of timeless quality. Blue hour light also coincides with yellow street lighting – in cities and suburbs, at least – which makes for a beautiful warm-cool contrast.

Here are a few examples of the beautiful light you'll find during blue hour:

Of course, blue hour light does come with a tradeoff: while it's wonderfully soft, it's also very weak, so working during this time of day can be tough. Photographers generally bring tripods and remote releases (discussed in detail below), and for the best shots, you'll often need to use extremely lengthy shutter speeds .

Note: The times before and after blue hour can also be great for photography. Golden hour offers soft, warm light, while the pre-dawn and post-dusk light can make for stunning nightscapes, so you certainly shouldn't feel like the blue hour is the only time you can capture outstanding images.

When does the blue hour occur?

Technically, blue “hour” is a misnomer. Depending on the weather and your geographical location, blue hour lasts from just a handful of minutes to around 45 minutes.

Therefore, if you want to take advantage of the beautiful light, you must act fast! I highly recommend you download an app like PhotoPills , which will give you specific blue hour times for your location and time of year. (PhotoPills also indicates when the golden hours start and end, which is also highly useful for most forms of photography!)

At the very least, you should research sunrise and sunset times the night before your photoshoot, then arrive on location early and set up in advance. If possible, find a nice composition or two. And once the magic begins, shoot away!

Note that, if you're looking to capture blue hour shots before sunrise, it's generally a good idea to scout the location the day prior. Trying to find compositions in the darkness can be tough, so if you can get this done in advance, you'll dramatically improve your chances of capturing great shots. Conversely, if you're aiming to capture blue hour shots after sunset, make sure you know exactly how to get back to your car, and don't forget to bring a flashlight; you don't want to get stranded with 8+ hours of darkness on the way!

The best blue hour photography settings

During blue hour, the sky becomes relatively dark, so you'll need a long shutter speed or a high ISO to get a good exposure , both of which come with significant tradeoffs. You also (generally) want a narrow aperture , which will render an entire scene sharp and in focus. So you need a camera mode that offers extensive control over your exposure variables.

Aperture Priority mode allows you to set the ISO and the aperture, while your camera sets the shutter speed for a well-exposed result. Manual mode lets you select the ISO, the shutter speed, and the aperture. Either of these can work, though Aperture Priority is generally the better choice for beginners, while Manual mode is more suited to a professional workflow.

If you go the Aperture Priority route, you should set an aperture that will keep the entire shot sharp (f/8 is a good starting point), and set your ISO to around 100 (to prevent unwanted high-ISO noise). Then let your camera determine the proper shutter speed for a nice exposure.

If you decide you want a longer shutter speed than your camera selects – to create beautiful streaks out of moving clouds or moving water – you can narrow the aperture, which will consequently cause your camera to lengthen the shutter speed. If you decide you want a shorter shutter speed (to freeze motion), you can widen the aperture or raise the ISO, though bear in mind that a wider aperture will reduce the depth of field, while a higher ISO will introduce noise into the image 。

If you go the Manual mode route, simply dial in your camera's base ISO and a nice aperture (just as if you're using Aperture Priority). Then set the shutter speed so that your camera's exposure meter is roughly balanced. If you need to increase or decrease the shutter speed, then make sure you also increase or decrease another exposure variable (ie, the aperture or ISO) to keep the exposure meter balanced.

One thing to keep in mind: Because blue hour tends to look relatively dark, your camera may try to overexpose the scene, which will ultimately create an unnatural-looking result (and may cause blown-out highlights). If you're using Aperture Priority mode, you'll need to add some negative exposure compensation to counteract this tendency, and if you're using Manual mode, you'll need to deliberately underexpose by a stop or two.

The best advice I can give is to always check the LCD preview and histogram after each image, and if you find that the photos are looking too bright (or too dark), take steps to correct the issue.合理？

The best gear for blue hour photography

Because the blue hour offers such limited light, you need specialized gear to ensure your photos stay sharp and noise-free. Here are my recommendations:

A full-frame camera

While you can absolutely capture beautiful blue hour shots using any camera – including a smartphone – a full-frame DSLR or mirrorless camera offers one huge advantage: It'll let you ramp up the ISO as needed without overwhelming your images with noise.

As I mentioned above, it's best to keep your ISO as low as possible, but if you're photographing moving subjects, working handheld, or doing astrophotography, keeping the ISO at 100 isn't always an option. Plus, the higher you can raise your ISO, the more flexibility you'll have and the faster you can shoot (waiting around for your camera to finish a five-minute exposure isn't always a ton of fun!).

That's when a full-frame camera will come in handy. The newest mirrorless models – such as the Sony a7 IV , the Canon EOS R5 , and the Nikon Z6 II – tend to perform best at high ISOs, but older and/or cheaper models can work great, too.

A fast lens

Most blue hour landscape and cityscape photography is done at narrow apertures, so a lens with an f/1.8 maximum aperture isn't necessary – but if you want to do blue hour street photography, portraiture, or astrophotography, a lens with a wide maximum aperture will make a huge difference. You'll be able to use handholdable shutter speeds without boosting your ISO to 12800, and you'll be able to freeze moving subjects, too.

If you're just starting out, I'd recommend grabbing a prime lens with a maximum aperture of at least f/2.8, and an f/1.8 maximum aperture is even better. You can pick up one of these models for cheap (such as a 50mm f/1.8), so you won't need to worry about breaking the bank.

三脚架

In my experience, the average blue hour shutter speed sits somewhere between one and six seconds. If you dial in such a lengthy shutter speed and then try to shoot handheld, you'll end up with frustratingly blurry shots.

Of course, you can always boost your camera's ISO to compensate for a shorter shutter speed, but the noise is often unbearable. And while you can widen your lens's aperture to f/2.8 and beyond, you'll lose the deep depth of field effect that is so prized by landscape, architecture, and cityscape shooters.

So for the best results, you really must use a good tripod .

A tripod will hold your camera in place while you shoot a 1-second, 6-second, or even 30-second exposure. Make sure you invest in a sturdy model; while there are plenty of cheap options out there, most of them will struggle to handle your setup, especially in wind.

If you're the type of photographer who walks long distances or travels frequently, I'd recommend a carbon fiber tripod, which combines sturdiness with portability. Otherwise, an aluminum model is fine (they tend to be on the cheaper side, but they're also a lot heavier). Whatever you do, however, do not buy plastic . It's just too flimsy.

A remote release

Even once your camera is mounted on a tripod, pressing the shutter button can cause camera shake, which will create blurry photos.

That's where a remote shutter release can help. It's a little handheld device that'll let you trigger your shutter from a distance. And this, in turn, will prevent any extra camera vibrations.

Happily, remote shutter releases are pretty cheap. You can get basic models – which generally consist of a single button and nothing else – for around $20. If you want to do serious long-exposure photography or time-lapse photography, you might consider grabbing a slightly more sophisticated remote (some options feature LCD screens with timers, interval-shooting functions, and more).

That said, if you want to get started with blue hour photography right away or you really don't like the idea of a remote release, you do have a few other options. You might be able to connect your camera to your phone and trigger it with an app. Alternatively, you can use the two-second self-timer function (the delay will give shutter-button vibrations time to die off). Neither of these options is wildly convenient – phone connections are often unreliable while self-timers throw off split-second timing – but they'll work in a pinch.

A neutral density filter

The blue hour is an incredible time for capturing breathtaking long-exposure shots. However, despite the lower light conditions during this period, you may still face challenges when trying to shoot at ultra-slow shutter speeds, such as 10 seconds or longer, without causing overexposure.

To overcome this hurdle, a crucial piece of gear comes into play: the neutral density filter. This handy accessory easily attaches to your lens and effectively blocks out excess light, allowing you to extend your shutter speed without any issues. With a high-quality neutral density filter, you can achieve impressive long-exposure blue hour shots with shutter speeds ranging from 10 seconds to even an hour.

It's important to invest in a reliable filter – there are some low-cost options available that result in unpleasantly soft photos. Make sure to choose a reasonably high-quality neutral density filter to ensure your images turn out sharp!

手电筒

When you venture into the enchanting world of blue hour photography, there's one more item you simply can't leave behind: a flashlight. This trusty tool serves multiple purposes and ensures that you're fully equipped for a blue hour adventure!

First and foremost, a flashlight is indispensable for finding your way in the dark. Whether you're setting up your gear before sunrise or wrapping up your shoot after sunset, a reliable light source helps you navigate safely through the shadows.

A flashlight also unlocks the potential for creative exploration. By using light painting techniques, you can add a touch of magic to your blue hour shots. With a bit of flashlight movement, you can selectively illuminate your subject or even create captivating light trails, adding an artistic flair to your images.

Finally, when shooting in low-light conditions, it can be challenging for your camera to find focus. This is where a flashlight comes to the rescue. By directing its beam towards your subject, you provide a clear point of reference, making it easier for your camera's autofocus to lock onto the desired focal point.

What types of photos should you take during the blue hour?

Blue hour is all-around wonderful, so don't let your genre of choice restrict you from heading out for some ethereal blue light. You can shoot moody street scenes or long-exposure architectural images. You can even capture gorgeous blue hour portraits by combining flash and natural light (more on this below!).

That said, blue hour is most suited to landscape and cityscape photography. It combines colors, clouds, long exposures, and flattering light – pretty much everything from the serious landscape and cityscape photographer's playbook. Scenes that are generally motionless but include a few moving elements – such as a beach with waves lapping at the shore – make for especially gorgeous blue hour shots. These types of images do take some patience and a bit of extra gear, but with the right approach, you can capture photos that really shine.

The only types of images you should avoid during the blue hour are those that highlight action subjects, such as wildlife photography, bird photography, and sports photography. The low light makes it tough to capture sharp files, so it's best to tackle these photos during the day.

Of course, it's sometimes necessary to shoot action during this time period, but you'll need to take an approach that's different to the one I recommended above; instead of using a tripod and a slow shutter speed, you'll need to boost your ISO and widen your lens aperture until your shutter speed is at least 1/100s (and ideally much faster). You'll also want to use a lens with a wide maximum aperture (f/2.8 at minimum). That way, you can freeze your subjects in motion!

13 tips for beautiful blue hour photography

Yes, blue hour is a great time to take photos. But you can't just head out in the evening, find an interesting subject, and start pressing that shutter button. Instead, you need to combine lovely blue hour light with technical know-how, which is where these tips come in handy:

1. Photograph both in the morning and the evening

While most photographers head out to shoot in the evening, the blue hour isn't just limited to the period after sunset. Similar light can be achieved in the morning, too! And depending on when you photograph, you can find very different subjects and conditions.

During the blue hour in cities, buildings are lit and streetlights come on, making it an ideal time for urban and cityscape photography with a perfect blend of natural and artificial light. The sky takes on a deep blue hue with cold tones and warmer colors from the illuminated buildings. A gradient of colors from blue to orange tinges the sky in place of the sunrise and sunset.

But while the colors and quality of light are often the same, shooting in the morning will give you much quieter, empty scenes, while shooting at night will give you much more chaotic shots (often with lots of cars and passersby).

2. Use a wide-angle lens for expansive shots

When capturing those mesmerizing blue hour photos, reach for a wide-angle lens! These lenses are perfect for capturing expansive scenes that make your viewers go “wow.” With a wide-angle lens, you can take in breathtaking vistas, city skylines, and much more.

Why go wide? Well, these lenses offer a generous field of view, allowing you to include more in your frame. The wide-angle effect adds an extra punch to your shots, especially when you include interesting foreground elements (see the next tip!).

Not only that, but wide-angle lenses are great for reducing blur caused by camera shake. So, even if your tripod isn't the sturdiest or you're dealing with less-than-ideal weather conditions, your images will come out sharper with a wide-angle lens.

You don't need an ultra-wide focal length either; even a 24mm or 35mm lens can work wonders for capturing the magic of the blue hour.

3. Incorporate foreground and background elements to add depth

Looking to level up your blue hour compositional skills? One effective technique is to incorporate interesting elements in both the foreground and the background of your shot.

Imagine you're photographing a stunning cityscape during the blue hour. Look for a striking skyline that catches your eye as your background element. It could be a cluster of towering buildings or a unique architectural structure. Then, find a compelling foreground element to complete the composition. It could be a stone pathway, a reflective puddle, or a line of trees.

By combining these elements, you give your photo a sense of three-dimensionality. It's like inviting the viewer to step into the frame and explore the scene. The foreground and background work together to create a visually engaging image that grabs attention.

Pro tip: Be sure to use a relatively narrow aperture to keep both the foreground and background elements sharp. And if your foreground subject is very close to the lens, you might want to try a focus-stacking technique to ensure everything remains in focus!

4. Shoot in RAW (and post-process your photos)

It's basic advice, but shooting in RAW over JPEG makes a big difference, especially when photographing blue hour scenes.

为什么？ RAW files provide outstanding post-processing flexibility. You can easily adjust the exposure and colors of a RAW file, and these adjustments are often the difference between a stunning shot and a mediocre one.

For instance, you can bring up the shadows in a RAW photo to reveal all sorts of lovely details. You can also bring out the blues and pinks in the sky, enhance the warmth of artificial lighting, and even darken the edges of the frame, which will push the viewer's eye toward your main subject.

And while you can make some adjustments to JPEGs, the effects are much more limited. Plus, if you adjust a JPEG too much, you may start to see unpleasant artifacts, such as banding.

RAW files do come with a drawback: They need editing. (A RAW file literally cannot be displayed in its original form; you must edit and convert it to a viewable format, first.)

But as I explained above, editing is a key part of every blue hour image. Without editing, you'll fail to bring out all the key details and colors in your shot.

So shoot in RAW and embrace the editing process. It's the fastest way to elevate your photos!

5. Consider manual focus for sharper blue-hour shots

If your camera's autofocus is struggling to find the right focus in the low light conditions of the blue hour, don't worry! You can switch to manual focus and take control.

Manual focus might sound intimidating, but it's actually quite simple. Just turn the focus ring on your lens until your subject appears sharp in the viewfinder or on your camera's screen. It also comes in handy when you're dealing with scenes featuring lots of depth; that way, you can set the focus exactly where you want it, ensuring maximum depth of field.

Bottom line: Thanks to manual focusing, you won't waste time waiting for the autofocus to catch up, and you'll have more control over the sharpness of your images. I encourage you to give it a try when you have some time to practice, and you'll see how easy it can be to get the perfect focus for your blue-hour shots.

6. Think about your subject and viewpoint

When preparing to take pictures during the blue hour, it is important to take on board a few considerations. What are you going to photograph and how will you frame your image?

My suggestion is to decide on your subject, and then consider what you want to include in your image. You may want to frame your subject with an attractive background or foreground to make the image look more visually pleasing.

I chose to photograph this night scene of Tokyo with the Rainbow Bridge as my main subject with the neon-lit cityscape and towering skyscrapers beyond:

7. Include electric lights in your images

Don't get me wrong: You can take amazing blue-hour photos of unaltered, naturally lit landscapes.

But in my experience, electric lights offer two benefits:

  1. They decrease exposure times. As the blue hour wears on, the sky will rapidly darken – and you may find your shutter speeds increasing to 10 seconds, 20 seconds, and beyond. However, an electric light or two will add extra illumination to the scene, thereby shortening your exposures and creating time for a few extra shots.
  2. They add drama and interest to your photos. If you use a narrow aperture (ie, f/8), electric lights will appear as beautiful starbursts, which can create a focal point or simply complement your main subject.

For instance, check out the image below, which relies on star-shaped lights to captivate the viewer:

Electric lights do come with some challenges, however. If you stand too close to a light source, you may get lens flare across your entire frame. And if you're not careful, electric lights can create major spots of overexposure in an otherwise well-exposed scene.

So don't get too close to the lights – the smaller the lights, the less problematic the flare and overexposure areas – and if you're struggling with exposure issues, check out my next tip:

8. Use HDR techniques to recover highlights

As I mentioned in the previous tip, photographing blue hour skies combined with electric lights can look amazing. Unfortunately, they can also result in all sorts of exposure problems, because electric lights are significantly brighter than their surroundings.

One approach is to expose for the electric lights and let the rest of the scene go dark. The idea is that you can then recover the shadows in post-processing – but this will introduce lots of noise, so it's really not ideal.

Another approach is to ignore the highlights. Expose for the rest of the scene, let the lights blow out, and embrace the resulting shot. This can work, but there's a better option that combines both of the approaches I've shared.

在蓝色时刻拍摄时，中性密度滤镜（ND 滤镜）是非常有效的工具。如果没有 ND 滤镜，当光线接近黄昏时，您可以将快门速度提高到几秒钟。

Blue hour photography FAQ

What is the blue hour?

The blue hour is a period of time before sunrise or after sunset when the sky takes on a beautiful blue hue. It's a magical time for photography!

What is the difference between blue and golden hour?

The blue hour occurs right before sunrise or after sunset when the sky is predominantly blue. Golden hour refers to the period just after sunrise or before sunset when the sun casts a warm golden light.

What shutter speed is best for blue hour photos?

The ideal shutter speed for blue hour photos depends on the effect you want to achieve. Generally, using a slower shutter speed of a few seconds or more can capture the serene and dreamy atmosphere.

Is blue hour the same as magic hour?

No, blue hour and magic hour are different. Blue hour occurs before sunrise or after sunset with a blue-toned sky, while magic hour refers to the time just after sunrise or before sunset when the light is soft and golden.

How do you shoot portraits in blue hour?

Shooting portraits during the blue hour can be challenging due to low light. However, you can use off-camera flash to illuminate your subject and create a balance between the subject and the background sky.
